ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I improved in my speaking ability as well as listening and reading comprehension. 
When I first started the course my teacher said I spoke English with Arabic words. Now much of my grammar is under control and my teacher and I have seen marked improvements. 

I have also learned a lot of vocabulary that has been useful in creating meaningful sentences. 

My proudest moments in the class were reading childrens books with little issue and creating my own story about a foreign student from Somalia who navigates fear-driven Islamophobia in the United States.
Stronger vocabulary, grammatical understanding, and overall fluency.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Since we were a small class of 5 students, we had plenty of time to practice speaking Arabic to one another. I think we should lean more into that. Sometimes we would spend most class going over homework drills. I didnt find this review helpful. Since there was so much to review, I often didnt have time to process what I got wrong on assignments. Giving us an answer key that we can check our answers to as needed would be more effective in my opinion. We could ask questions in class or in TA sessions as needed based on those results. I think class time should be spent solely on speaking Arabic, trying to use the new vocabulary, and reading aloud. I particularly struggled with reading aloud.

I appreciated grammar lessons as well. Oftentimes the teacher would ask us for topics that we needed help with and she would prepare lessons accordingly. However, we didnt always do this and we were sometimes tested on grammar topics we never went over in class such as the dual degree. 

I would organize the revised (3-day per week) schedule as such. Dedicate two of the three days for in-class speaking and reading practice. Take the last day and dedicate it to grammar. I know in the middle of the semester we had TA sessions every Friday, but those ended up being speaking sessions anyway as opposed to anything particularly unique. I dont think they were necessary.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I appreciated the break from Zoom by having us meet only three days a week as opposed to 5. However, the HW submission times were a little awkward. Homework on off-days was due at 12:00pm which was the middle of what would have been our meeting time. I would keep it consistent and have all HW due at midnight the day its assigned. It was a little challenging to keep up with the assignments. 

The HW submission process could be improved as well. Most teachers set up zoom so that you can submit any file type for HW. This is efficient because it interfaces well with most applications that we use on our various devices. In this class however, we were to submit in a Canvas-generated word processor that could take in photos. But the process for uploading those photos is tedious especially if youre using a device that doesnt take pictures. Towards the end of the semester, that particular system started breaking down (apparently I had reached a file-upload limit) and I had to submit HW as comments which are not always detected by teachers.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this course provides low-stress yet vigorous instruction in the intermediate level of the Arabic language. I learned a lot and Im sure after Arabic L4 next semester Ill be equipped to go abroad and take full advantage of the experience.
Yes, I would recommend. Great professor.
